Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Instrument Development for Biological Imaging
Award.AbstractNarration:
This CAREER award is for the development of a new generation of multiphoton microscopes to image deep and fast in scattering biological tissues. Specifically, three approaches will be used to improve the imaging depth and speed: (1) A longer wavelength spectral window will be used for multiphoton excitation with reduced scattering. (2) A new multiphoton imaging method will be developed, based on sum-frequency generation and non-degenerate two-beam, two-color fluorescence excitation to eliminate or reduce the excitation background in a scattering tissue, thus improving the penetration depth. (3) Sub-carrier modulation will be applied to multiphoton imaging and will be used to develop a new fast imaging technique that is compatible with deep imaging in a scattering environment.

The instruments to be developed will significantly extend the capability of multiphoton microscopy in biological research. Multiphoton microscopy is already an indispensable tool in biological imaging, and this research will help to solve the following two difficulties so that this microscopy can reach its full potential: (1) How to see deeper into tissues and (2) How to image faster. This research is interdisciplinary and will help to train students who will become interdisciplinary scientists. In addition, the principal investigator and his students will participate in outreach activities via various programs such as the GK-12 fellowship programs to promote physics teaching at the high school level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We demonstrated unequivocally that longer wavelength multiphoton microscopy (MPM) is superior for deep tissue penetration, and achieved a record 1.6 mm penetration in in vivo mouse brain. We have experimentally demonstrated the modulation imaging technique. We further demonstrated that the modulation imaging method is an ideal tool for fluorescence life time imaging, particularly for probes with a long lifetime. We have demonstrated the possibility of two-color two-photon excitation using our Ti:S pumped OPO. We experimentally demonstrated the advantage of sum frequency generation in reducing out-of-focus background in Collagen samples. Approximately one order of magnitude reduction of out-of-focus background was obtained.

By addressing the fundamental and practical challenges in deep tissue imaging, we have demonstrated long wavelength MPM that can routinely reach an imaging depth of 1 mm or beyond within intact biological tissues such as the brain. The finding of this program enables biological researchers in many fields for the first time to directly observe the behavior of cells with high spatial resolution within intact tissues at unprecedented depths (>1 mm).

The imaging acquisition speed for both MPM and MPM-FLIM is fundamentally limited by the maximum fluorescence generation rate (i.e. fluorescence saturation). Current technologies for fast MPM imaging are based on parallel excitation of multiple pixels at once, and require parallel data acquisition through imaging of signal photons by a multi-element detector (typically a CCD). While satisfactory in a neat sample or a thin slice of tissue, the signal emitted from different resolution volumes will be completely mixed due to scattering. In this program, we experimentally demonstrated a parallel-excitation and parallel-collection MPM-FLIM system that can obtain high pixel rate simultaneous lifetime and intensity imaging at depth in-vivo without imaging the signal photons, thus avoiding blurring due to scattering of the emitted light. Our method fundamentally allows fast FLIM data acquisition in a scattering tissue sample, opening significant new opportunities in important biological research fields.

Our work in deep tissue imaging has stimulated development in the laser and microscope industries. New laser sources were recently introduced for the longer wavelength spectral window. In addition, our work has also stimulated companies to develop new fluorescent probes at the longer wavelengths.

The graduate student supported by this funding developed a foundation for understanding ultrafast optics and acquired the numerical simulation and experimental skills necessary for building and testing an imaging system.

The PI serves as director of graduate studies (DGS) for the graduate field of applied physics. As a part of his responsibility, he is spending significant effort to attract URMs and women to his graduate field. The Applied Physics program also established a minority mentoring plan, with the DGS (PI) serves as the point contact for the URM students until they join a research group. The PI currently serves as faculty advisers for a number of student groups and organizations, such as the local Optical Society of America chapter and the Engineering Physics undergraduate student society. Both organizations have been heavily involved in out-reach programs to
local schools (K through 12) by partnering with the on campus NSF centers.
